pages.text: Uighuroniscus sinkiangensis is a fish from the Shengjinkou Formation of Xinjiang, China. This formation is part of the larger Tugulu Group, and represents a muddy lacustrine floodplain environment. It was described in 1985 by Chinese paleontologist Dezao Su, who interpreted it as a late surviving member of the Palaeonisciformes, a group which dominated ray-finned fish diversity from the Paleozoic into the early Mesozoic. Today, this wide grouping of palaeonisciform fish is understood to be paraphyletic, with extant ray-finned fishes likely evolving from them.

Still, Uighuroniscus bears a striking resemblance to far more primitive fish and represents a morphological relict. Whether it was more closely related to more derived fishes or represents a separate lineage of ancient Palaeonisciformes has not been well established, as this fish is incredibly obscure and has had almost no subsequent research. The name references the Uighur people indigenous to the Xinjiang region of China from which it was found.
